title: Did The Beatles song “Helter Skelter” start hard rock? - Quora

response.answer_text: I agree hard rock was done before, no matter what Paul McCartney says, (assuming this is what triggered the post) Remember, Macca admitted he heard the Who had released the loudest, most raucous song ever (I can see for miles) and wanted to top it; so even there, he was a follower, not a pioneer. But the White Album was released in ‘68, and as already posted, how do you ignore the work from Cream, and Hendrix? How about the Who using multiple 100-watt Marshall amplifiers in 1965, something never done before? What about Blue Cheer (summertime blues), or Steppenwolf’s Born to be Wild? Where do you begin? Have you ever sat in 4th row seats of the Jefferson Airplane in their prime (I have!)? There were a lot of loud and hard rock bands mid 60s!

I will say “no” because other groups were recording and releasing songs with a hard/harder edge. In fact one need look no further than Deep Purple’s first album “shades of deep purple” - that’s a hard rock album and was released in September 1968, two months before “the white album”. Other examples would include Iron Butterfly’s “in-a-gadda-da-vida” released early ‘68, and Steppenwolf’s hit “born to be wild” issued 1967.

I'd have to go with the Kink's/”You really Got Me”! ( One hell of a mean guitar solo by brother Dave at the break and it was 1964! Some still say it was Jimmy Page not Dave; but he's never confirmed it and Dave insists it's all him to this day! ) The next candidate also from 1964, I think, would have to be “Can't Explain"/the Who! Hard rock as hell! You might be able to throw in “My Generation” too? ( Actually you can go back to the 50′s and say some of the “Guitar Heroes" of the day like Link Ray, Eddie Cochran and other bad boys were kinda hard rockabilly rockers too! ) No Ventures, no Santo & Johnny, no Dick Dale/King of the Surf Guitar! All too light weight, “Surf” guitar, pop! Great stuff but not even rock n' roll actually.

That’s debatable. McCartney was trying to outdo The Who’s “I Can See For Miles” in terms of volume and heaviness, and he certainly succeeded. Hard rock morphed from the psych/garage style of a couple of years earlier, but by 1968 there was a lot of what would come to be known as hard rock and prototype-heavy metal, e.g., The Vanilla Fudge, The Iron Butterfly, Steppenwolf, and especially The MC5.

Many musicians and experts have credited it that way yes. At the very least it was influential in the development of it. But all of their music was influential in the development of new genres. This is why they were and remain the greatest.
CREAM, JIMI, MC5, BLUE CHEER, TED NUGENT… played Hard Rock before that (great) BEATLES’s track.
